posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>47206995
The problem is that the structure for a function definition looks something like this

identifier ( arglist ) identifierlist { Expressions }

So the code inside parseIdentifier is something like
if peek.val == '(' {
    parseArglist()
    if peek.val == ')' {
        if peek.type == identifier {
            parseIdList()
        }
        if peek.val == '{' {
            while peek.val != '}' {
                parseExpression()
            }
            return astNode //containing all the info about the function and it's body
        } else {
            //error
        }
    } else {
        //error
    }
} else {
     //error
}

and this isn't the full code, there's also the case where there's an identifier after an identifier (like when you declare a variable, i int for example.

So the problem isn't that there is a lot of branches on one conditional statement, but rather that there is long chains of conditions leading to these deeply nested if statements.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>47207168
Since this is intended for the lexing part it's hard to apply it to the parsing, the problem with doing recursive calls like this is that ultimately this function should consume a huge amount of tokens and put them together in a single node. If I return a function for parsing the arglist from the function parsing the identifier, it loses track of the fact that this arglist is the arguments to the identifier before it.

However it could be useful because I could do a second pass like this which would return fewer tokens (like an arglist token) which could simplify it, but I'm not really sure that's actually going to make the code simpler in the end.

Okay, /g/. I'm learning to program and need some clarification on structs.

The example on the C# reference page is this:

public struct Book
{
    public decimal price;
    public string title;
    public string author;
}


I get what it does. It creates a new struct which holds three new variables. I just have a few questions.

1. When would I want to use a struct and when would I want to make a "book" class and have individual "book"s inherit from it?

2. Could I declare a default value for the variables while making the struct, as in:

public struct Book
{
    public decimal price = 11.00;
    public string title = "Book";
    public string author = "Author's Name";
}


and then later when I make a Book, change anything that happens to be different?

The only difference I'm aware of between structs and classes (besides the fact that structs require certain values to be initialized I believe) is the pass by value behavior. When you pass a struct by value it copies all the data and creates a new object, while a class passed the same way you still have the same object after being passed.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>47207732
1. Do you need functionality that is specifically bound to this type of data? Use a class. Avoid inheritance, favor composition. Avoid classes as long as you do not have a lot of global state.
https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms173109.aspx
2. You can have struct constructors (https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/aa288208%28v=vs.71%29.aspx) but no explicit default values. Specific default values are generally considered bad style, especially for "data only", since using them gets rid of quite a bit of flexibility because it is not the responsibility of the data holder to decide which values it should hold.
The default values of structs are generally the default values of the types you are using, which are:
https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/83fhsxwc.aspx
Struct members are initialized to their default as well and all object types are pointers in C# so those are presumably initialized to null.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>47207809
>>47207880
>The only difference I'm aware of between structs and classes (besides the fact that structs require certain values to be initialized I believe) is the pass by value behavior.
Both objects and structs are passed by value. The only difference is that all objects are essentially safe pointers.
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/373419/whats-the-difference-between-passing-by-reference-vs-passing-by-value

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>47207880
There's probably millions of adequate explanations so I won't be redundant, but suffice it to say it's the difference between using the ref keyword in C# or not.

If you pass a struct by value to a function, changes made to the corresponding parameter variable inside the function have no effect outside the function because it creates a new object and copies the data into it when you call the function. If you change a class object inside a function, the changes will be reflected outside the function because they are operating on the same object (unless you reassign the parameter variable to another object in the function)
>>47207927
I never said structs/objects weren't both pass by value, just that they have different behavior when being passed by value. Structs are copied into a new object after being passed into a function while classes reference the same (unless reassigned)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>47208000
And I never said that your statement was incorrect, I was just adding something to your statement.
What's often confusing when researching this kind of stuff is that the word "reference" is often used terribly incorrectly, just to warn the person that originally asked the question.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>47207732
>>47207863
>There's no point in using structs in general outside of some specific use cases such as P/Invoke. Just use classes.

Depends on the use case.

Classes are going to be slower than structs in general, e.g. there was a 10x difference here.

https://nprogramming.wordpress.com/2010/06/01/c-performance-class-vs-struct/

Though take note that when they tried to use OOP features (in this case interfaces) with structs, it slowed down again, so it's probably not worth doing.

Anyway if a programmer were worried about performance they would put the performance-critical sections in C and import them into C#.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>47208252
You can use some static XPath (ugly).

>>47208267
You create a md5 hash for each image, store it in the database. When someone wants to check how many duplicates there are you create the md5 hash of the new image and then do a lookup for matching entries and spit out the results.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Is this the best way to do FizzBuzz in C# console?

using System;
using System.Collections.Generic;
using System.Linq;
using System.Text;
using System.Threading.Tasks;

namespace FizzBuzz
{
    class Program
    {
        static void Main(string[] args)
        {
            int number;
            for (number = 1; number <= 100; number++)
            {
                Console.Write (number.ToString() + " ");
                if (number % 3 == 0)
                {
                    Console.Write("Fizz");
                }
                if (number % 5 == 0)
                {
                    Console.Write("Buzz");
                }
                Console.WriteLine();
            }
            Console.ReadKey();
        }
    }
}

posts.com:
>>47208433
>It seemed better than having "FizzBuzz" be its own conditional and doing "if (number % 3 == 0 && number % 5 != 0)" for the first one.
generally its better to reduce occurrences of modulo, comparisons and conditionals, but in this case you are not strictly adhering to the specifications since you're printing numbers with a trailing space, and in the most common version of fizzbuzz the number isn't supposed to be printed out together with the text.

as a small exercise you could try building a string your way and then print the entire output in one go.
